docs.lead_paragraph: Actors Equity has reached a contract agreement for the actors at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum. The 12 actors, who joined the union in August, perform in ''Embracing Freedom,'' a story of immigrants' coming to America. Under the contract, the actors' daily salary will rise to $115 from $113, with a 3 percent raise next year. Daily pay for understudies, formerly $78, will also climb to $115. The new agreement includes health insurance, pensions, paid sick days and a promise from management to do its best to provide two dressing rooms near the theater. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pact For Actors At Ellis Island

docs.abstract: Actors at Ellis Island Immigration Museum, who perform in Embracing Freedom, story of immigrants' coming to America, will receive salary increase and benefits (S)

byline.original: By Steven Greenhouse (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: Profit and Revenue Rise In Quarter for Microsoft Microsoft reported a strong quarter with both profits and revenue up sharply at a time when the economy is weak and technology spending is depressed. Revenue grew 26 percent, to $7.75 billion. Operating profit increased 40 percent, to $4 billion, and net income more than doubled, to $2.7 billion, or 50 cents a share. Microsoft gained from customers rushing to sign up for a new licensing program, but its performance also showed that it was succeeding in persuading personal computer makers and users to buy the larger and more costly business version of Windows. [Page C4.]
docs.snippet: Profit and Revenue Rise In Quarter for Microsoft  Microsoft reported a strong quarter with both profits and revenue up sharply at a time when the economy is weak and technology spending is depressed. Revenue grew 26 percent, to $7.75 billion....

docs.lead_paragraph: Businesses, responding to lawmakers and consumers, say they are giving customers more ways than ever to control how their personal information is used and sold. But, in fact, many companies all but frustrate their customers' attempts to exercise that control. Barbara Bechtold of Sacramento recounts the unending process of trying to keep companies from selling her e-mail address and the details of her credit card accounts, insurance policies and mortgage inquiries.
docs.abstract: Businesses, responding to lawmakers and consumers, say they are giving customers more ways than ever to control how their personal information is used and sold; some states are taking on what they consider most blatant lies about whether consumer gives permission to share or sell e-mail address and other information; New York State has sued online marketer MonsterHut over unsolicited e-mail messages, which MonsterHut insists were sent with permission; decision in case is pending; consumer privacy advocates have complained about practices at Yahoo, where members who want to tell company not to spread around their e-mail addresses and interests or to send them e-mail offers had to click through more than dozen boxes that were checked to accept mailings (M)
docs.snippet: Businesses, responding to lawmakers and consumers, say they are giving customers more ways than ever to control how their personal information is used and sold. But, in fact, many companies all but frustrate their customers' attempts to exercise that...

docs.lead_paragraph: HealthSouth, the nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals and clinics, said yesterday that it was suspending its plan to spin off the surgical centers that are its most lucrative business. Richard M. Scrushy, HealthSouth's founder, said that under pressure from lenders and investors he was withdrawing the plan, which would have made him chief executive of a nominally independent surgery business. He had resigned as chief executive of HealthSouth while staying on as its chairman.

headline.main: HealthSouth Suspends a Plan To Spin Off Surgery Centers

docs.abstract: HealthSouth is suspending its plan to spin off surgical centers that are its most lucrative business; founder Richard M Scrushy says that under pressure from lenders and investors he is withdrawing plan, which would have made him chief executive of nominally independent surgery business; HealthSouth stock has plummeted 69 percent, to $3.61, since Aug 27, when company announced spinoff and said its cash flow might be cut by as much as $175 million this year because Medicare would be paying lower rate for physical therapy for some patients; HeathSouth and Scrushy attracted scrutiny from investors, who raised questions about timing of his sales of company's shares and independence of board; Scrushy sold shares for $74 million in May and repaid $25 million loan to company July 31 by returning shares; Securities and Exchange Commission and law firm hired by HealthSouth are investigating; company is also defendant in whistle-blower lawsuits, including one joined by Justice Department; suit claims HealthSouth committed fraud in billing Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: HealthSouth, the nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals and clinics, said yesterday that it was suspending its plan to spin off the surgical centers that are its most lucrative business.    Richard M. Scrushy, HealthSouth's founder, said...

docs.lead_paragraph: Confronted with a budget impasse and an approaching election, Congress agreed tonight to finance government agencies until late November and put off much of an unfinished legislative agenda to a post-election lame-duck session. The Republican-led House, defying Democratic critics, voted 228 to 172 to keep federal agencies running at current spending levels until Nov. 22, and the Democratic-led Senate quickly followed suit.

headline.main: Congress Delays Budget Until After Election

docs.abstract: Congress, confronted with budget impasse and approaching election, agrees to finance government agencies until late November and put off much of unfinished legislative agenda to a post-election lame-duck session; House recesses, but Senate could remain in session into coming week (M)
docs.snippet: Confronted with a budget impasse and an approaching election, Congress agreed tonight to finance government agencies until late November and put off much of an unfinished legislative agenda to a post-election lame-duck session.    The Republican-led...

docs.lead_paragraph: Few politicians go far without knowing how to sidestep a tough question, put off a painful decision with a blue-ribbon panel or avoid taking a strong position until the winds of popular opinion blow one way or another. But even among accomplished political practitioners, Gov. George E. Pataki stands out. Behind his country-boy charm, he is a disciplined campaigner who has perfected the art of saying as little as possible.

headline.main: By Saying Very Little, Pataki Sticks to Script

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki is disciplined campaigner who has perfected art of saying as little as possible; that tendency is most pronounced as race for governor enters final stretch; he often responds to pointed questions by saying he is proud of his record, then ignoring question itself; his stategy appears to be to stress his leadership, strike confident tone and avoid being dragged into detailed policy debate with his opponents that might cast doubt on his abilities or record; he is strong front-runner, and is putting off stating positions on controversial issues until after Election Day; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Few politicians go far without knowing how to sidestep a tough question, put off a painful decision with a blue-ribbon panel or avoid taking a strong position until the winds of popular opinion blow one way or another.     But even among accomplished...
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: It seemed like another routine appearance for Gov. George E. Pataki last month when he showed up at a Manhattan restaurant to give a short speech in honor of Hispanic Heritage Month. But in a few minutes the well-heeled celebrators in the crowd were putting down their sangria glasses, shouting ''All right!'' and applauding wildly. ''Nuestros barrios son mas fuertes, nuestro estado es mas fuerte,'' Mr. Pataki said. ''Porque tenemos una comunidad Latina muy fuerte.'' (Our neighborhoods are stronger, our state is stronger, because we have a very strong Latin community.)

headline.main: Speaking the Language, and the Issues, Pataki Makes Inroads With Latino Voters

docs.abstract: New York Gov George Pataki, seeking election to third term, appears to be gaining support in traditionally Democratic Hispanic community; has been aggressively courting Hispanic vote, speaking Spanish--albeit poorly--and taking up causes that appeal to Hispanic voters; Democrats view his efforts as too little, too late, but Republican tactics appear to be working if polling numbers are accurate; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Oct. 9 editorial about the mental health care crisis in New York State highlights an imploding tragedy that is playing out across the country. Each year, more than 3.5 million people with mental disorders turn to a state mental health system that often fails them. Consistent cuts in mental health services have caused the severely mentally ill to crowd hospital emergency rooms, street corners and now nursing homes. Children with undiagnosed and untreated mental disorders are at risk for substance abuse and delinquency. Untreated mental illness costs United States employers at least $80 billion in lost productivity a year.
docs.abstract: Dr Paul S Appelbaum letter on Oct 9 editorial on mental health care crisis in New York State

docs.lead_paragraph: The cost of health benefit plans at big companies will rise more than 15 percent next year on average, according to a study by Hewitt Associates Inc., a private human resources consulting firm. As a result, many companies are not only making employees pay a larger share of their health care benefits, but are also considering health plans that try to cut costs by making employees take responsibility for their health care spending.

headline.main: Costs of Health Benefits Are Seen Rising by 15%

docs.abstract: Hewitt Associates Inc says cost of health benefit plans at big companies will rise more than 15 percent next year on average; says many companies are not only making employees pay larger share of their health care benefits, but are also considering health plans that try to cut costs by making employees take responsibility for their health care spending; expects average cost increases of 15.4 percent in 2003, on top of 13.7 percent rise recorded this year (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Squabble Over Bids Delays Sale at a Vivendi Business Vivendi Universal has delayed the auction of its publishing business as it continues to squabble with potential buyers over the dwindling value of their bids, executives involved in the process said. The delay raises questions about whether Vivendi will be able to complete a sale this year. Vivendi's chief executive, Jean-René Fourtou, above, who took over in July, has been trying to cut the company's debt load of $16.7 billion. [Page C4.]
